ã€

#â€‹537 â€” January 8, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Happy New Year to all. In case you missed our note prior to the Christmas break, Go Weekly is now published on Wednesdays â€“ we were missing too many high profile items that were landing late on Tuesdays, seemingly a common day for Go releases. Fingers crossed this helps us be even more timely!Â ğŸ¤
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

Go Weekly

Go Developer Survey 2024 H2 Results â€” The results of the latest Go community survey are out. Over 4000 responses were analyzed with developers largely being satisfied with Goâ€™s direction, but finding maintaining consistent coding standards to be the biggest challenge. Linux and macOS lead the way with OS choice, VS Code and GoLand for IDEs, and AWS when it comes to clouds. We also get some interesting stats on the level of LLM use by GoÂ developers.

Alice Merrick

Master the Fullstack â€” Expand your abilities to the server with this comprehensive learning path. You'll learn how to create APIs, build containers, deploy code, set up servers, and muchÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

How I Program with LLMs â€” The co-founder of Tailscale shares his thoughts on modern approaches to writing Go code with numerous LLM-powered techniques and shares off a new LLM-powered â€˜Go playgroundâ€™ heâ€™s workingÂ on.

David Crawshaw

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ§ We're sad to hear that the Go Time podcast is bowing out with its latest episode reflecting on eight years and 340 episodes of shows. However, Fallthrough is a new Go podcast that picks up Go Time's torch.

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ If you want to attend this year's GopherCon UK, you can now save the date: it's in London on August 13-15. No rush, though, its CFP doesn't even open tillÂ March.

  • ğŸ“º A variety of talks from GopherCon 2024 (which took place in July) have begun to land on YouTube, including â–¶ï¸ a look at extending the Go compiler, â–¶ï¸ building a firewall with Go, and â–¶ï¸ code instrumentation techniques in high performance trading systems.

  • ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ On the topic of GopherCon, GopherCon 2025 takes place this August 26-28 in New YorkÂ City.

  • Juho ForsÃ©n reflects on a year of security fixes in Go.

Rust vs Go in 2025 â€” An updated look at a topic that John often covers but with the same conclusion as ever: itâ€™s worth knowing bothÂ languages.

John Arundel

Build Go Apps using Project IDX and the Gemini API â€” IDX is a Google-developed AI-assisted online workspace for full-stack app development. Hereâ€™s the bare basics of getting started with it for GoÂ work.

Mueller and Saba (Google)

Pixel Federation Swaps MSK for WarpStream, Saves 83% on Kafka Costs â€” By swapping AWS MSK for WarpStream, Pixel Federation drastically reduced Kafka costs and eliminated complex VPCÂ peering.

WarpStream sponsor

ğŸ“º Why CGO is Dangerous â€“ A short, engaging and relatively high-level critique ofÂ CGO. Rachel Lettuce

ğŸ“„ Go Union Type Proposals Should Start with Their Objectives â€“ There have been a few proposals to add union types to Go, but Chris thinks they focus more on semantics thanÂ objectives. Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Go is a Well-Designed Language, Actually Matt Hall

ğŸ“„ Why Go Should Sometimes Be a No-Go â€“ By way of contrast, this developer simply doesnâ€™t find Go fun enough, yet.. is switching back toÂ Java..! Brain Baking

ğŸ“„ Docker on macOS is Still Slow? â€“ A handy comparison of the performance of differentÂ approaches. Paolo Mainardi

ğŸ“„ Writing and Testing a Paginated API Iterator in Go Thibaut Rousseau

ğŸ“„ Write Your Own json.Unmarshal TinyBirdPerson

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

betteralign 0.6: Make Your Programs Use Less Memory.. Maybe â€” A tool to detect structs that could use less memory if their fields were organized differently. Itâ€™s a fork of Goâ€™s fieldalignment tool that skips generated or test files, skips specially marked structs or those with anonymous fields, doesnâ€™t drop comments, and similar DXÂ enhancements.

Dinko Korunic

Fuego: A Nest-Inspired API/Web Framework for Go â€” â€œThe only Go framework generating OpenAPI documentation from code. Inspired by Nest, built for Go developers.â€ Hereâ€™s a hello world example along with full docs. The latest version (0.17) adds (initial) Gin routerÂ support.

Fuego, Inc.

templ: A Way to Build HTML with Go â€” Create components that render fragments of HTML and compose them to create screens, pages, documents, and apps. GitHubÂ repo.

Adrian Hesketh

  • Mockery 3.0 Alpha â€“ Creates mock implementations of interfaces.

  • Caddy 2.9 â€“ Powerful Go-powered HTTP/1-2-3 server with automaticÂ HTTPS.

  • Pebble 2.0 â€“ RocksDB/LevelDB inspired key-value database in Go. Used by CockroachDB under theÂ hood.

  • River 0.15 â€“ Fast and reliable Postgres-powered background jobs forÂ Go.

  • go-github v68.0 â€“ GitHub v3 API clientÂ library.

  • GoBGP 3.33 â€“ BGP implementation inÂ Go.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ”¹ Sell to enterprise with a few lines of code with WorkOS â€” the modern, flexible identity platform for B2B SaaS. Integrate SSO, SCIM and FGA in minutes, notÂ months.

ğŸ˜ Postgres user? Check out our sister newsletter, Postgres Weekly which starts its 2025 run of issues tomorrow.

ğŸ And one for fun..

Memos: A Privacy-First Go-Powered Note Taking App â€” A complete, MIT-licensed note taking webapp that you can self host and which continues to see frequent updates. It uses Echo as a framework and stores its data in a SQLite file. GitHubÂ repo.

Memos Contributors

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹539 â€” January 22, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go 1.24 Release Candidate 2 Released â€” Weâ€™re another step down the road to the eventual release of Go 1.24, and the Go team are particularly keen for you to kick the tires of the second release candidate: â€œRun it in dev! Run it in prod! File bugs!â€ RC2 isnâ€™t a significant jump from RC1 but the draft release notes continue to improve and Anton Zhiyanovâ€™s Go 1.24 interactive tour will get you up toÂ speed.

Michael Knyszek

ğŸ’¡ Go 1.23.5 and 1.22.11 have also been released including a couple of securityÂ fixes.

Protect Against Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in RealÂ Time â€” With WorkOS Radar you can detect, verify and block harmful behaviour, protecting your app with advanced device fingerprinting. Stop fake signups, stop free tier abuse, and stop bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

Workos sponsor

â–¶Â Â How to Build an MMO Game with Godot 4 and Go â€” A thirteen video YouTube series on building a multiplayer online game using the popular Godot game engine (no relation to Go) and with Go handling theÂ backend.

Tristan Batchler

IN BRIEF:

  • IDE developer JetBrains has launched the Early Access Program for GoLandÂ 2025.1, its popular Go IDE. One cool thing about the EAP is they're free to use so can act as an extended trial ofÂ sorts.

  • For Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) users, gomaxecs provides a way to automatically set GOMAXPROCS based on ECS task and container CPU limits.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ ParaGopher is a retro style arcade game written with Ebitengine.

â–¶Â Â Go in the Smallest of Places â€” A GopherCon 2024 talk about the potential and technicalities of using TinyGo to build Go-powered systems onÂ microcontrollers.

Patricio Whittingslow

ğŸ“„ Mind the convT: Avoiding convT Performance Bottlenecks â€“ The creators of a Go-powered database system explain how they tackled interface-related bottlenecks in theirÂ code. Max Hoffman

ğŸ“„ 'I Made an Online PS1 Game and Connected It to a PS4' â€“ Delightfully esoteric. The game is written in C but Go is used to tie everything together behind theÂ scenes. Carl Llewellyn

ğŸ“„ SQL Transactions in Go: The Good Way Thibaut Rousseau

ğŸ“„ Go Interfaces: Why, How and When Noam Yadgar

ğŸ“„ How to Write Better Tests in Go Jakub Jarosz

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Forgejo 10.0: A Go-Powered Self-Hosted Software Forge â€” Think Gitea (indeed, itâ€™s a fork of it â€“ more on that here) but with even more features make it a full on GitHub replacement. It powers the Codeberg platform and you can see it in action in Forgejoâ€™s own repo. A new version 10.0 has justÂ dropped.

Forgejo Team

asyncmachine-go: A Declarative Control Flow Library â€” Implements AOP and the actor model through a clock-based state machine for building autonomous, statefulÂ workflows.

Kentaro Hibino

gno.land Offers Grants & Bounties for Go-Powered Decentralized Apps â€” App builders, Go enthusiasts, tinkerers: come and build on gno.land, a smart contract platform for a freer, fairerÂ world.

gno.land sponsor

Bunster: Compile Shell Scripts to Static Binaries â€” bash scripts are already quite portable, but if you want to transpile them to Go and turn them into binaries, here youÂ go.

Yassine Benaid

  • VHS 0.9 â€“ CLI 'home video recorder'. "Write terminal GIFs as code for integration testing and demoing your CLIÂ tools." v0.9 adds a Wait keyword for waiting for certain conditions before continuingÂ (as above).

  • ğŸ¤– Mods 1.7 â€“ Charm's pipeline-able AI CLI client. Now with improved GitHub Copilot support and OpenAI o1Â support.

  • â˜ï¸ phonenumbers 1.5 â€“ Go port of Google's libphonenumber library for parsing and validating phoneÂ numbers.

  • GoReleaser 2.6 â€“ Build/release binaries for multipleÂ platforms. v2.6 gains Bun and Deno support.

  • OpenTelemetry-Go 1.34 â€“ OpenTelemetry Go API andÂ SDK. Now requires GoÂ 1.22+.

  • Notify 1.3 â€“ Library to send notifications to variousÂ services.

  • gocryptfs 2.5 â€“ Encrypted overlay filesystem written inÂ Go.

  • Inngest 1.4 â€“ Stateful workflow orchestration platform.

  • sqlc 1.28 â€“ Generate type-safe Go code fromÂ SQL.

  • Miniflux 2.2.5 â€“ Go-powered feed reader app.

item.title: ã€A continued focus on the benefits of Go 1.24ã€‘ç»§ç»­å…³æ³¨GO 1.24çš„å¥½å¤„
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹540 â€” January 29, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go 1.24's go tool is One of the Best Additions in Years â€” Go 1.24 isnâ€™t even fully here yet (though rc2 is out) and people are already very excited. One major enhancement is the new go tool command and tool directive in go.mod, which simplifies handling dependencies for dev-time tooling and improves performance by caching runs and reducing dependencyÂ bloat.

Jamie Tanna

ğŸ’¡ John Howard has another take in Exploring the go tool support in GoÂ 1.24

Keep Your Apps Fast and Error-Free with Honeybadger â€” Honeybadger helps you fix errors, eliminate performance bottlenecks, and dig into the details faster than ever before. With support for Go, Ruby, and 8 other languages, itâ€™s the best way to gain real-time insights into your applicationâ€™s health andÂ performance.

Honeybadger sponsor

Proposal: A Way to Reduce Error Handling Boilerplate with ? â€” A proposal to streamline error handling using a ? operator. This new syntax could reduce boilerplate by optionally handling errors and returning early or executing an error handlingÂ block.

Ian Lance Taylor

IN BRIEF:

  • Cloudflare published an interesting blog post about how they handle over 100GB/sec of logs and Go sits at the heart of it.

  • JetBrains, the developers of the GoLand IDE, has unveiled Junie, a new 'coding agent' to which you'll be able to delegate various coding tasks in future. It's behind a waitlist for now but looks promising.

  • The OpenTelemetry project has announced Alibaba, Datadog and Quesma have joined forces to enable the use of zero-code, vendor-neutral compile-time instrumentation in Go apps.

Maps are Faster in Go 1.24 â€” Itâ€™s thanks to so-called Swiss Tables and you donâ€™t need to make any changes to benefit from the new implementation. Just upgrading to Go 1.24 will unlock theÂ gains.

Byte Size Go

Go Slices: Shared Memory and append() Pitfalls â€” A look at some potential tripping points in Go when it comes to working with slices and sub-slices. Rob Pikeâ€™s 2013 post on the official Go blog is also a great resource on thisÂ topic.

Patrick A. Noblet

Protect Against Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time â€” WorkOS Radar protects your app with advanced device fingerprinting â€” stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

WorkOS sponsor

ğŸ“„ Scripting with Go â€“ How to â€˜sprinkle some Unix shell fairy dust on your Go programsâ€™ to build shell-like data pipeline operations. John Arundel

ğŸ“„ So You Wanna Write Kubernetes Controllers? â€“ From someone who leads LinkedInâ€™s Kubernetes management, noÂ less. Ahmet Alp Balkan

ğŸ“„ Bridging Rust and Native Go â€“ â€œa feasible way to build native Go bindings from Rust and C components with the magic power of purego and libffiÂ behinds.â€ Hanchin Hsieh

ğŸ”’ FIPS Mode for Red Hat Go Toolset â€“ Red Hat Go Toolset is a Red Hat distribution of Go that lets apps use OpenSSL forÂ crypto. David Benoit

ğŸ“„ cURL Project and Go Security Teams Reject CVSS as Broken Sarah Gooding (Socket)

ğŸ“„ Deploy a Server using Go with GitLab and Google Cloud Claire Champernowne (GitLab)

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Centrifugo v6: A Scalable Real-Time Messaging Server â€” Imagine an open source, self-hosted equivalent to Pubnub or Pusher for passing messages to users of real-time apps over WebSocket, HTTP streaming, SSE, and more. Itâ€™s language agnostic, but written in Go. GitHubÂ repo.

Centrifugal

Maddy 0.8: A Composable All-in-One Mail Server â€” Can work as an MTA, accept messages via SMTP, store messages and even provide access to them over IMAP. v0.8 requires Go 1.23+ but adds support for HAProxyâ€™s PROXY protocol and handling DNS-01 challengeÂ records.

Max Mazurov

  • ğŸ“Š go-echarts 2.5 â€“ Charting and data visualization library that uses ApacheÂ ECharts. You can see examples in theÂ docs.

  • FerretDB v2.0 RC â€“ A Go-powered MongoDB implementation built on top of Postgres andÂ DocumentDB.

  • gRPC-Go 1.70 â€“ Go implementation of gRPC for HTTP/2 basedÂ RPC.

  • Ergo 2.15 â€“ A modern IRC server (daemon/ircd) written in Go.

  • Tokenizer 0.3 â€“ Go implementation of OpenAI'sÂ tokenizer.

  • quic-go 0.49 â€“ Pure Go QUICÂ implementation.

  • GoProxy 1.7 â€“ HTTP proxy library for Go.

  • Garble 0.14 â€“ Obfuscation for GoÂ builds.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ’¡ Modern Infrastructure Demands a Modern Approach to Privileged Access - Read WhiteÂ Paper.

By swapping AWS MSK for WarpStream, Pixel Federation drastically reduced Kafka costs and eliminated complex VPC peering.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in Dev

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader developer landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • GitHub has been doing some work on improving issues, by adding support for sub-issues, issue types, and advanced search forÂ issues.

  • SRCL is a neat new suite of React components for creating webapps with a monospaced, terminal-style aesthetic.

  • If you ever need to work with JavaScript server-side, Bun 1.2 is a huge release for an increasingly popular, high performance JavaScriptCore-based Node-a-like. It 'just works' for a lot of stuff where Node gives meÂ headaches.

  • Like a deep, technical read? Using the most unhinged AVX-512 instruction to make the fastest phrase search algorithm goes into ridiculousÂ depth.

  • Take a look at every byte that goes over the network when making a real Postgres query over TLS (above). Everything is annotated to help you understand theÂ complexity.

item.title: ã€An interactive tour of Go 1.24ã€‘1.24çš„äº’åŠ¨ä¹‹æ—…
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹538 â€” January 15, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

An Interactive Tour of Go 1.24 â€” A list of all the significant new 1.24 features. Each is accompanied by interactive, runnable examples so you can see generic type aliases in action, make (and clean up) weak pointers, play with file access, and see benchmarks for the new faster mapÂ implementation. Go 1.24 is expected to land in the next month or two, with RC2 likely later thisÂ week.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ If you've not experienced Anton's Go tours before, you might also enjoy the Go 1.23 interactiveÂ tour.

The First Newsletter Dedicated to Product Engineers â€” The fastest growing startups increasingly rely on product engineers. They can both figure out what to build and actually build it. Product for Engineers is dedicated to sharing the skills and strategies needed to succeed in thisÂ role.

PostHog sponsor

if got, want: A Simple Way to Write Better Go Tests â€” â€œThereâ€™s an excellent Go testing pattern that too few people know. I can teach it to you in 30 secondsâ€ is quite the pitch. The trick is using both assignments and a comparison on a single if line to make a test easier to read â€”Â itâ€™s even used in the standardÂ library.

Michael Lynch

Gophers Pack: A Collection of Gopher Pictures and DesignÂ Elements â€” If you want some handy Go gopher themed images to use for a project, blog post, or presentation, this myriad of cute CC0 (public domainish) elements could be a big help. We use them a lot in this newsletter and Maria has recently added a variety of winter themedÂ options.

Maria Letta

A Practical Example of Dependency Inversion using Plugins â€” An example of using Clean Architecture principles with Goâ€™s plugin package to create an app thatâ€™s adaptable and extendable without modifying the core sourceÂ code.

Christian Ekrem

Realizing Why Go Reflection Restricts What Struct Fields Can Be Modified â€” Private (unexported) fields canâ€™t be modified, even when using reflection. When looking at this through Rust-colored glasses, it makes moreÂ sense.

Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ How HTTP/2 Works and How to Enable It in Go â€“ One of Phuongâ€™s typically thoroughÂ explanations. Phuong Le

ğŸ“„ Designing a Distributed Circuit Breaker for Disabling Webhook Endpoints â€“ If youâ€™re consuming a lot of third-party APIs, this could help keep your queues fromÂ clogging. Raymond Tukpe (Core Gateway)

ğŸ“º The Creator of Ghostty Talks Zig over Go â€“ Controversial. Mitchell Hashimoto (of HashiCorp fame) has recently built Ghostty, a fast new terminal emulator, in Zig. But why notÂ Go? ThePrimeTime

ğŸ“º Implementing a Random Art Generation Algorithm â€“ A thorough walkthrough of a way to generate curious graphicalÂ elements. package main

ğŸ“„ Making 'Beautiful' API Keys â€“ Making auth tokens/keys more attractive probably shouldnâ€™t be a priority, but if you want/need to, uuidkey may be forÂ you. Jack Spirou (AgentStation)

ğŸ“„ Modifying Private Variables of a Struct with unsafe and reflect â€“ Remember itâ€™s called unsafe for aÂ reason... Darshan N A

ğŸ“„ Scaling LLMs with Go: How We Serve Millions of LLM Requests John Wang (Assembled)

ğŸ“„ We Removed 335 LOC with One Go Package â€“ Going from generating a huge number of ffmpeg directives to a cloud-based audio transformationÂ approach. Poxate

ğŸ“„ How rqlite, a Go-Powered SQLite-Based Database, is Tested Philip O'Toole

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

go-mail v0.6: A Library for Sending Emails â€” If youâ€™ve got email to send, go-mail can do the job. v0.6 adds support for S/IME signing, SMTP auth auto-discovery, Unix domain socket support, and a â€˜quick sendâ€™ feature.

Winni Neessen et al.

ebpf-go 0.17: A Way to Work with eBPF from Go â€” A pure Go library to read, modify and load eBPF programs for use directly by the Linux kernel (eBPF is a neat technology worth exploring if youâ€™re not familiar with it yet). The new 0.17 release requires Go 1.22+ and introduces a new API to work with globalÂ variables.

Beckers et al.

go-haystack: Track Personal Devices via Apple's 'Find My' Network â€” An interesting way to track personal Bluetooth devices via Appleâ€™s massive â€œFind Myâ€ network by way of TinyGo and a little extraÂ hardware.

Ron Evans

  • GoCV 0.40 â€“ The Go bindings for OpenCV 4 add support for OpenCVÂ 4.11.0.

  • pgxmock 4.4 â€“ Mock driver to test Postgres interactions inÂ Go.

  • Cloudflare Go 4.0 â€“ Official library for the CloudflareÂ API.

  • FrankenPHP 1.4 â€“ Modern Go-powered PHP appÂ server.
